title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text: Repository: https://github.com/matteo-torres/ejscreen-LA

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
Background
Los Angeles County, home to approximately 9.6 million residents, is one of the most diverse regions in the United States. About 30% of its population identifies as people of color, and around 14% are classified as low-income or living in poverty (US Census). Many of these individuals have been adversely affected by the generational impact of historical redlining, a practice that began in the 1930s under the Home Owners‚Äô Loan Corporation (HOLC).
The term ‚Äúredlining‚Äù originates from HOLC‚Äôs use of color-coded maps to rank neighborhoods, with green designated as the best and red labeled as hazardous. This practice systematically deepened racial segregation, excluding communities of color from neighborhoods deemed ‚Äúgreen,‚Äù and primarily benefiting white individuals and neighborhoods. As a result, perceptions of neighborhoods shifted, along with the allocation of resources, living conditions, and overall quality of life for those in red areas.
Evidence suggests that the HOLC grading system is associated with numerous adverse health outcomes and poorer environmental characteristics in present-day neighborhoods (Swope). Some of these include higher levels of pollution, limited access to healthy food, and increased surface temperatures. Despite the passage of time, many residents of Los Angeles continue to bear the consequences of living in these historically redlined areas, which have seen little to no improvement in quality.
The purpose of this study is to statistically analyze current data to understand how pollutants and socioeconomic factors may correlate with life expectancy in Los Angeles County. My goal is to identify trends that deepen our understanding of the current situation in communities that have historically experienced disparities.

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text: Highlights

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles Countyy
text: Data Descriptions

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
About the Data
For this study, I chose to utilize the EJScreen: Environmental Justice Screening and Mapping Tool dataset provided by the Environmental Protection Agency. This CSV file contains a variety of variables that assess different environmental burden indicators, socioeconomic indicators, and health disparity indicators, with Census block groups serving as the primary geographic unit.
To begin my analysis, it is essential to filter the dataset to include only observations from Los Angeles County, select the relevant variables for measurement, and remove any entries with missing data.

Dependent Variable
The primary focus of this statistical analysis is to measure how life expectancy responds to environmental and socioeconomic factors.

Low Life Expectancy: This measure identifies areas where life expectancy is lower than the national average.

EJScreen employs an inverse approach, where higher values correspond to lower life expectancy, and lower scores indicate higher life expectancy. The percentage of low life expectancy is calculated using the formula:
% Low Life Expectancy = 1 - (Life Expectancy / Max Life Expectancy)


Independent Variables
Environmental Burden Indicators

Particulate Matter 2.5 (PM 2.5): This metric quantifies potential exposure to fine particulate matter (2.5 micrometers or smaller) and is expressed as the annual average concentration in the air, measured in micrograms per cubic meter.
Ozone: The ozone indicator in EJScreen reflects the annual mean of the 10 highest daily maximum 8-hour (MDA8) ozone concentrations.
Hazardous Waste Proximity: This indicator considers the total number of hazardous waste facilities within a 10-kilometer radius of the average resident in each block group, adjusted for distance. It is calculated as a population-weighted average of the blocks within each block group.

Socioeconomic Indicators

People of Color: This group includes individuals who identify as a race other than ‚Äúwhite alone‚Äù and/or identify their ethnicity as Hispanic or Latino.
Low Income: A household is classified as low income if its income is equal to or less than twice the poverty level, defined as $29,950 by the U.S. Census Bureau.



Limitations
Before continuing onto my analysis plan, it‚Äôs important to acknowledge the limitations of the EJScreen dataset.

This tool is not intended to provide a comprehensive risk analysis. Instead, it functions as a screening tool to examine certain issues related to environmental justice. It does not encompass all relevant issues that should be considered, and it strives to balance the need for data quality and national coverage while including as many significant environmental factors as possible within the constraints of available resources.
The dataset relies on demographic and environmental estimates that carry a considerable degree of uncertainty, especially when analyzing smaller geographic areas.

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
Citations
Environmental Protection Agency. (2024). EJScreen: Environmental Justice Mapping and Screening Tool. epa.gov. https://www.epa.gov/ejscreen/download-ejscreen-data
Swope, C.B., Hern√°ndez, D. & Cushing, L.J. The Relationship of Historical Redlining with Present-Day Neighborhood Environmental and Health Outcomes: A Scoping Review and Conceptual Model. J Urban Health 99, 959‚Äì983 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11524-022-00665-z
United States Census Bureau. (2023). Quick Facts Los Angeles County, California. Census.gov. https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/losangelescountycalifornia

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
Limitations

This tool is not designed to provide a comprehensive risk analysis. Instead, it serves as a screening tool to explore important issues related to environmental justice.
It is based on demographic and environmental estimates that carry a considerable degree of uncertainty, particularly when analyzing small geographic areas.

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
Analysis
Goal: Explore the relationship between environmental pollutants and socio-economic factors, controlling for confounding variables.

Correlation Analysis


Regression Models

title: Exploring Environmental Justice in Los Angeles County
text:
Analysis Plan

Correlation Analysis

Analyze the pairwise correlations among Environmental Burden Indicators, Socioeconomic Indicators, and Low Life Expectancy.



Regression Models

Model 1: Utilize simple regression to predict life expectancy based on environmental burden indicators (pollutants).
Model 2: Implement multiple linear regression by including socioeconomic indicators as additional predictors.
Model 3: Examine interaction effects to understand how socioeconomic indicators influence the relationship between environmental burden indicators (pollutants) and low life expectancy.

According to the pairwise correlation analysis, which quantified the linear relationships between all variable pairs, there is a moderately positive association between hazardous waste proximity and exposure to particulate matter (PM 2.5). There is also a moderately positive association between the percentage of people of color and the percentage of low-income individuals. However, there is a moderate negative association between hazardous waste proximity and the ozone indicator.
While these moderate relationships may provide insights into the situation in Los Angeles County, we cannot assume that correlation implies causation. It is essential to further analyze the data in different ways to gain a clearer understanding of whether these relationships are causal.


Regression Models
Model 1: Simple Regression
lm(lifeexppct ~ pm25 + ozone + ptsdf, data = los_angeles)

Simple Regression Model

Adjusted R-squared: 0.06091

The results indicate that both ozone levels and proximity to hazardous waste sites are significant predictors of life expectancy, as evidenced by the low p-values. The negative coefficient for ozone suggests that areas with higher ozone levels tend to have lower life expectancy. On the other hand, the positive coefficient for proximity to hazardous waste sites indicates that regions closer to these sites also tend to have lower life expectancy. However, the model explains only about 6.1% of the variation in life expectancy, which implies it may not fully account for all the factors influencing this outcome. There may be other variables not included in the model that could have a more substantial impact on life expectancy.
Model 2: Multiple Regression
lm(lifeexppct ~ pm25 + ozone + ptsdf + peopcolorpct + lowincpct, data = los_angeles)

Based on the new model, both particulate matter (PM 2.5) and ozone levels show a negative and statistically significant relationship with life expectancy. This indicates that higher pollution levels are linked to lower life expectancy. Additionally, communities located closer to hazardous waste sites also tend to have lower life expectancy. The analysis reveals that higher percentages of people of color and low-income individuals are associated with lower life expectancy, highlighting the compounded effects of environmental and socioeconomic factors in vulnerable communities. The model now accounts for approximately 24.8% of the variation in life expectancy, which is a significant improvement over the previous model. This suggests that incorporating both environmental and socioeconomic variables has enhanced the model‚Äôs fit.

In contrast, the interaction between ozone levels and the percentage of low-income individuals is not significant, suggesting that income levels do not influence the negative effects of ozone on life expectancy. Approximately 27.73% of the variability in life expectancy is explained by this model, which shows an improvement to previous models, likely due to the inclusion of interaction terms.

According to this interaction model, the significant interaction effect indicates that low-income communities are more vulnerable to the negative impacts of living near hazardous waste sites. In contrast, the non-significant interaction between proximity to hazardous waste and the percentage of people of color suggests that the racial composition of a neighborhood does not significantly influence the health effects of living near these sites. The model accounts for approximately 25% of the variance in life expectancy.
Further exploration of potential interactions between other environmental pollutants and socioeconomic factors could provide deeper insights. This exploration may reveal instances of omitted variable bias, which occurs when an important factor is left out of the analysis. Additionally, we could consider model improvements by incorporating variations of effects from other variables and interactions to enhance the overall the analysis.

title: Matteo Torres
text:
I was worried you might have gotten lost on the way‚Ä¶
Hi, I‚Äôm Matteo!
I‚Äôm a graduate student dedicated to building data science skills to solve complex environmental challenges. With a focus on ecology, conservation, and restoration, I aim to drive meaningful insights and advance solutions in environmental data science.
Now that you‚Äôre here, feel free to look around and get to know me better!
If you‚Äôd like to connect or see what I‚Äôve been working on, don‚Äôt hesitate to drop me an email or check out my GitHub!

title: About Me
text:
Background
I grew up in Wilmington, CA, a small neighborhood in the South Bay and Harbor region of Los Angeles. The area has a predominantly Hispanic/Latino population and is home to a working-class community. Wilmington is located adjacent to the Port of Los Angeles and is home to the third-largest oil field in the continental United States. Several major oil refineries, including Marathon, Phillips 66, Valero, and Tesoro, are based here, making it a critical hub for the region‚Äôs industrial and energy infrastructure.
Living in this environment has deeply inspired me to pursue environmental data science. Growing up surrounded by industrial activity, pollution, and environmental challenges has fueled my desire to contribute something positive to my community. I aim to use my education and skills to work on projects focused on environmental justice, conservation planning, and biodiversity monitoring. Through data-driven solutions, I hope to help create a more sustainable and equitable future for communities like mine.








Pollution is racial violence. Photo by Michael Estrada, sourced from Patagonia and Wilmas Youth for Environmental Justice.





Video source: Patagonia. District 15 | Stop Neighborhood Oil Drilling. Communities for a Better Environment works to empower California communities in the fight for environmental justice. This short film highlights the resilience of Wilmington‚Äôs young activists as they advocate for a Los Angeles City Council ban on oil and gas drilling within 2,500 feet of homes, schools, and hospitals.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text: Redlining has historically contributed to disparities in the United States. It originated in the 1930s when the Home Owners‚Äô Loan Corporation (HOLC) assessed neighborhoods for lending risk, which led to racial segregation and the promotion of affluent white neighborhoods. Today, neighborhoods that were marked as ‚Äúred‚Äù continue to face economic disadvantages, including higher poverty rates and lower economic mobility (Swope, Hern√°ndez, and Cushing 2022). Despite the gradual movement toward reparations, significant geographic disparities persist in biodiversity monitoring and conservation planning, leading to a lack of attention and resources for ‚Äúred‚Äù communities. Recognizing and addressing these disparities is crucial for advancing conservation priorities and accurately protecting biodiversity.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text: Redlining has historically contributed to disparities in the United States. It originated in the 1930s when the Home Owners‚Äô Loan Corporation (HOLC) assessed neighborhoods for lending risk, which led to racial segregation and the promotion of affluent white neighborhoods. Today, neighborhoods that were marked as ‚Äúred‚Äù continue to face economic disadvantages, including higher poverty rates and lower economic mobility (Swope, Hern√°ndez, and Cushing 2022). Despite the gradual movement toward reparations, significant geographic disparities persist in biodiversity monitoring and conservation planning, leading to a lack of attention and resources for ‚Äúred‚Äù communities. Recognizing and addressing these disparities is crucial for advancing conservation priorities and accurately protecting biodiversity.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text:
Case Study
There has been a significant increase in the availability of biodiversity data, largely driven by technological advances. According to the article ‚ÄúHistorical Redlining is Associated with Increasing Geographical Disparities in Bird Biodiversity Sampling in the United States,‚Äù a study shows that digital collections created by citizen scientists using cellphone apps, such as eBird, tend to be spatially biased. Specifically, higher-income areas are overrepresented while low-income areas are undersampled (Ellis-Soto, Chapman, and Locke 2023). Although this issue may seem minor, databases like eBird play a critical role in conservation decisions. This bias can dramatically affect measurements of biodiversity change, making it more difficult to accurately map and forecast species distributions.
Citizen science plays a vital role in monitoring biodiversity, but relying solely on it for conservation planning and resource allocation can introduce bias and negatively impact biodiversity, particularly in underrepresented areas. Research has indicated that eBird activity correlates with income and racial demographics at the census tract level. As a result, bird populations are often undersampled in lower-income communities, reflecting a bias in sampling associated with historical redlining (Grade et al. 2022). This raises concerns about the missing data that could significantly impact these excluded communities. Moreover, there is a notable disparity between the racial composition of the general public and the birdwatching community, which predominantly consists of white individuals, with very limited representation of Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (Rutter et al. 2021). As mentioned earlier, the long-term effects of historical redlining have fostered predominantly white neighborhoods, which helps explain why eBird data may not accurately represent the broader population.
eBird has implemented a diverse range of products, including outreach materials, environmental assessments, and conservation plans. According to the article ‚ÄúUsing Open Access Observational Data for Conservation Action: A Case Study for Birds,‚Äù eBird has played a crucial role in species assessments, such as identifying the rufa Red Knot as a threatened species and implementing policies to restrict wind energy in certain areas (Sullivan et al. 2017). However, it is noted that eBird has not yet reached a sufficiently large audience. To realize its full potential, intensive partnership building, a strong community, and time will be necessary. Although these products positively impact environmental science, there is a risk from using a platform that has poorly conducted data, which can potentially misinform policy and practice (Konno et al. 2024). Biased bird observation data can be problematic because it may introduce inaccuracies that could affect our understanding of conservation priorities and ultimately lead to the decline or even extinction of truly threatened species populations.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text:
Reflection
There are two significant sources of bias present in the eBird data: availability bias and volunteer bias. Availability bias occurs when we rely on the most readily accessible data‚Äîin this case, the eBird app. As a result, the data may not adequately represent the target population as intended. On the other hand, volunteer bias arises when participants in a study have traits that differ from the general population of interest (Nunan, Heneghan, et al. 2017--2024). In this context, it pertains to the socioeconomic status of bird watchers. Determining representativeness is complicated when the available data does not capture the relevant characteristics of either the sampled users or the larger population (Olteanu et al. 2019). These biases pose significant limitations to the use of the data due to uncertainties and cold spots. Furthermore, they raise ethical concerns, as the eBird observations may reflect patterns of redlining.

How can we address redlining when the necessary data is lacking?

How might this missing data affect the allocation of resources for disadvantaged areas?

Although it may not be intentional, how can we bridge the socioeconomic gap among birdwatchers?

Scientists, policymakers, the general public, and the eBird platform should carefully consider how they utilize bird observation datasets and seek ways to improve these disparities.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text:
Solutions
To promote equitable biodiversity research and conservation, it is crucial to align scientific goals with community-led initiatives. By prioritizing the improvement of biodiversity sampling in underrepresented regions, often referred to as coldspots, and collaborating with neighborhood associations and non-governmental groups, we can encourage inclusive citizen science. Programs like STEM-focused initiatives for high school students, Black Birders Week, and Latino Outdoors are examples of how engaging marginalized communities can enhance scientific literacy and encourage broader participation in nature-based activities. Furthermore, by leveraging federal initiatives like Justice40, resources can be directed to historically underserved communities, empowering them with K-12 STEM education and promoting active involvement in conservation efforts.‚Äã Until we see a change in the data that reflects the population, tools like eBird can eventually be used to improve environmental science and policy. By embracing these strategies, we can develop a more inclusive and informed approach to biodiversity conservation.

title: Addressing the Impact of Redlining on Biodiversity Conservation
text:
Citations
Konno, K., Gibbons, J., Lewis, R., & et al.¬†(2024). Potential types of bias when estimating causal effects in environmental research and how to interpret them. Environmental Evidence, 13(1). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13750-024-00324-7
Olteanu, A., Castillo, C., Diaz, F., & Kiciman, E. (2019). Social data: Biases, methodological pitfalls, and ethical boundaries. Frontiers in Big Data, 2. https://doi.org/10.3389/fdata.2019.00013
Rutter, J. D., Dayer, A. A., Harshaw, H. W., Cole, N. W., Duberstein, J. N., Fulton, D. C., Raedeke, A. H., & Schuster, R. M. (2021). Racial, ethnic, and social patterns in the recreation specialization of birdwatchers: An analysis of United States eBird registrants. Journal of Outdoor Recreation and Tourism, 35, 100400. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jort.2021.100400
Sullivan, B. L., Phillips, T., Dayer, A. A., Wood, C. L., Farnsworth, A., Iliff, M. J., Davies, I. J., Wiggins, A., Fink, D., Hochachka, W. M., Rodewald, A. D., Rosenberg, K. V., Bonney, R., & Kelling, S. (2017). Using open access observational data for conservation action: A case study for birds. Biological Conservation, 208, 5‚Äì14. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biocon.2016.04.031
Swope, C.B., Hern√°ndez, D. & Cushing, L.J. The Relationship of Historical Redlining with Present-Day Neighborhood Environmental and Health Outcomes: A Scoping Review and Conceptual Model. J Urban Health 99, 959‚Äì983 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11524-022-00665-z
